message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows a classic pattern of cavernous hemangioma, which is a common benign liver tumor. Hepatocellular adenoma has a different histologic appearance. Focal nodular hyperplasia typically has a central stellate scar. Angiosarcoma has a different histologic appearance and is a malignant tumor.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hyperechoic mass in the left lobe of the liver and the photomicrograph suggest the most likely diagnosis is cavernous hemangioma. Hepatocellular adenoma is less common and is usually associated with oral contraceptive use or pregnancy. Focal nodular hyperplasia has a central scar and angiosarcoma is rare and more aggressive.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows a cavernous hemangioma, which is the most common benign tumor of the liver. Hepatocellular adenoma can also occur in the liver, but it is less common than cavernous hemangioma. Focal nodular hyperplasia is another type of benign liver tumor, but it has a different appearance on imaging studies. Angiosarcoma is a rare malignant tumor of blood vessels and is not consistent with the imaging findings in this case.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows a cavernous hemangioma, which is a common benign liver tumor that presents with abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, and fullness after eating. Hepatocellular adenoma is more common in women and associated with oral contraceptive use. Focal nodular hyperplasia also presents with liver mass but usually has central scarring. Angiosarcoma is a rare malignant tumor that presents with hepatomegaly, ascites, and weight loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows large, thin-walled vessels filled with blood, which is characteristic of cavernous hemangioma. Hepatocellular adenoma can have a similar appearance but is usually smaller and more cellular. Focal nodular hyperplasia has a central scar and angiosarcoma would show malignant cells invading the liver tissue.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows a cavernous hemangioma, which appears as a well-defined mass with multiple blood-filled spaces. Hepatocellular adenoma and angiosarcoma both present as single solid masses. Focal nodular hyperplasia appears as a well-demarcated nodule with central scarring.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows dilated blood vessels and fibrous tissue, which is consistent with cavernous hemangioma. Hepatocellular adenoma is associated with oral contraceptive use and often multiple in number. Focal nodular hyperplasia has a central fibrous scar and a characteristic classic stellate scar. Angiosarcoma is a rare malignant tumor that presents with abdominal pain and weight loss.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The hyperechoic mass on ultrasound and the photomicrograph of the resected specimen suggest cavernous hemangioma, which is a common benign liver tumor. Hepatocellular adenoma may have a central scar, while focal nodular hyperplasia has a characteristic central stellate scar on imaging. Angiosarcoma is a rare malignant tumor with different histologic features.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows a well-circumscribed mass with vascular channels and dilated sinusoids, which is characteristic of a cavernous hemangioma. Hepatocellular adenoma would show sheets of hepatocytes with little to no normal liver structure, Focal nodular hyperplasia would show central stellate scar and fibrous septa, and angiosarcoma would show poorly differentiated malignant cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The photomicrograph shows a classic appearance of a cavernous hemangioma, which is the most likely diagnosis based on the patient’s symptoms and imaging findings. The other options are less likely based on the appearance of the specimen.
